docs.snippet: I was hoping my 4-year-old would see the library as I once did, as a hushed building full of endless promise. Instead, it’s become an arcade.

docs.snippet: In "Home Game" at the Kitchen on Friday night, the ends meant little; the means meant much. Developed by Todd Hivnor and a team of computer programmers, "Home Game" begins with two actors onstage, six more on videotape and an ensemble of acoustic and...
docs.lead_paragraph: In "Home Game" at the Kitchen on Friday night, the ends meant little; the means meant much. Developed by Todd Hivnor and a team of computer programmers, "Home Game" begins with two actors onstage, six more on videotape and an ensemble of acoustic and electrified instruments. These, together with a collection of plot situations and character motivations, provide nutrition for a computer that artfully shuffles the ingredients and produces a story line. Three large screens define the performing space. From one at stage left, the two actors read the bits of narrative as the computer has arranged them. Another screen at stage right provides cues and musical materials for the musicians. These, like the shuddering, repetitive images of video characters on the center screen, have been configured to match the computer's story line. When the computer shuffles again, the same elements produce a somewhat different narrative.

headline.main: Plots That Rely on Shuffling the Pieces

docs.snippet: So, who doesn't want to be a millionaire? The folks behind the cameras, including the one with the question cards, are just as greedy as the rest of us, and the real question asked in ''Game Show,'' a spunky spoof of America's perennially popular...
docs.lead_paragraph: So, who doesn't want to be a millionaire? The folks behind the cameras, including the one with the question cards, are just as greedy as the rest of us, and the real question asked in ''Game Show,'' a spunky spoof of America's perennially popular television fare by Jeffrey Finn and Bob Walton, is just how far they are willing to go to claw their way to the top of the network pyramid. In fact, ''Game Show'' is a sort of cross between a traditional quiz program and ''Survivor'' in which the last man or woman standing after a no-holds-barred brawl of television politics takes all. With the double-crossing, back-stabbing power struggles shuffled in with an actual trivia-quiz program in which contestants drawn from the audience play for real prizes, ''Game Show'' is not only a funny comedy but also lots of fun.
docs.abstract: Wilborn Hampton reviews Jeffrey Finn and Bob Walton play Game Show, directed by Mark Waldrop; photo (M)

headline.main: Although It's a Show, This Game Is For Real

docs.snippet: MAC OBSERVER  www.macobserver.com       FOR Macintosh addicts, one of the most energetic geek sites on the Web is the Mac Observer, which is updated several times a day. The site is a full-service on-line magazine, with news reports, original...
docs.lead_paragraph: MAC OBSERVER www.macobserver.com FOR Macintosh addicts, one of the most energetic geek sites on the Web is the Mac Observer, which is updated several times a day. The site is a full-service on-line magazine, with news reports, original stories, opinionated columnists and editorials that celebrate, cogitate and occasionally berate Apple Computer's creations.
docs.abstract: Mac Observer, Web site featuring technical information, advice and product reviews to Macintosh computer users, evaluated (S)

docs.snippet: Valve, the uncorporate but influential video game company, thinks it may be onto the next big thing in games: wearable computing.
docs.lead_paragraph: Valve, the uncorporate but influential video game company, thinks it may be onto the next big thing in games: wearable computing.
docs.abstract: Valve, uncorporate but influential video game company, may be onto the next big thing in games: wearable computing; its new goggles could unlock game-playing opportunities, letting players lose themselves inside a virtual reality and eventually blend games with their views of the physical world; company tries to foster unorthodox thinking by having no traditional management structure.
